newsitem.title: USA: Boeing and McDonnell Douglas to collaborate.
newsitem.headline: Boeing and McDonnell Douglas to collaborate.

text.p: Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. reached an agreement Tuesday to collaborate on future Boeing wide-body commercial airplane programs.
In a joint statement, the aerospace companies said the first project McDonnell Douglas will work on is the development of new versions of the Boeing 747 jumbo jet.
The move comes as Boeing faces record orders for its commercial aircraft and McDonnell Douglas is looking for ways to keep its employees working.

"(This) allows us to keep our skilled teams together at a period when we have minimal commercial development activity underway," said Tom Downey, spokesman for St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas. He added that the deal will allow the company to remain on the cutting edge of airplane design.
"We are looking at a long-term colloborative, strategic arrangement for wide-bodies," he said.
Wall Street viewed the deal as a positive for both companies, allowing Boeing to meet its ever-growing backlog while giving ailing McDonnell Douglas time to assess its options.

"It's looks like a good deal for Boeing because they get the extra capacity, and for McDonnell it raises the issue (of) 'What's going to become of that commercial business? Do they become a potential takeover?'," said Cai Von Rumohr, analyst at Cowen & Co.
Von Rumohr said McDonnell may seek a more permanent partnership either with Boeing, Europe's Airbus Industrie or an Asian company, or it could opt to carve out a niche as a preferred sub-contractor.
McDonnell Douglas has looked directionless in recent months. In November it lost a lucrative bid to build a next-generation fighter plane for the Pentagon.

In October, the company shelved plans to build the MD-XX, a long-range commercial aircraft aimed at competing with the 747. That decision effectively ended the company's ambitions of competing with Boeing and Airbus as a full-fledged commercial airplane manufacturer.

"Their position as a mainstream player is not as strong as it has been," Von Romohr said. "This has happened gradually over time. The decision not to go ahead with the MD-XX in essence opened up the potential to take on this role with Boeing."
Boeing said it was looking forward to working closely with McDonnell Douglas.

"We have a record number of orders for commercial jets and several ongoing development programs," said Ron Woodard, president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. "McDonnell Douglas has excellent design and production capability -- both in people and facilities -- that are not being fully utilized.
"We look forward to applying those resources to future Boeing wide-body airplane programs in a way that is a win-win for both of us."

Boeing said initially the agreement was expected to bring several hundred McDonnell Douglas employees to Seattle in January to begin assisting with engineering design and analysis on the 747-500X/-600X.
The agreement should be finalized in January.
McDonnell's stock was unchanged at $52.625 and Boeing slipped 12.5 cents to $97.375 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
